thread.title: Woodard still fuming about 'targeting' call against Ellis
thread.title_full: Woodard still fuming about 'targeting' call against Ellis

author: Danny Shapiro
title: Woodard still fuming about 'targeting' call against Ellis
text:
Woodard still fuming about 'targeting' call against Ellis Danny Shapir , Beaumont Enterprise By Danny Shapiro Published 12:24 pm, Thursday, October 8, 2015 
Four days later, Lamar coach Ray Woodard was still fuming about two calls that changed the scope of the Cardinals' loss to Southeastern Louisiana. 
With the Cardinals leading 14-13 late in the first half of Thursday's game, senior cornerback Seth Ellis was called for a targeting penalty on a nine-yard pass to Lions receiver Jeff Smiley . 
Ellis left his feet to hit Smiley in the helmet, which by definition of NCAA Rule 9-1-4 states that Ellis was to be disqualified from the remainder of the game because he "initiated contact to the head or neck area of a defenseless opponent with the helmet, forearm, fist, elbow or shoulder." 
The rule came into effect at the start of the 2014 season to help protect receivers and provide oversight over targeting calls through the use of official review to determine the validity of a the call. 
Smiley, as a wide receiver, was deemed a defenseless receiver in this situation and upon official review, Ellis was ejected despite it being his first offense, much to the dismay of Woodard. 
"Seth played it like we taught him," Woodard said. "It was a hard hit. I did not think it should have been targeting." 
The call came back to haunt the Cardinals late in the fourth quarter when Ellis' replacement, freshman Rodney Randle , surrendered a 41-yard pass play on 3rd and 11 on the Lions' game-winning drive. 
On the Cardinals' final drive, the rule was not enforced when Woodard believed it should have been. 
Trailing 30-27 with less than a minute remaining and on their own 17-yard line, the Cardinals ran a draw play to junior running back Kade Harrington . 
Harrington found space to the outside and was spun by a defender at his own 35-yard line, then was hit by a second defender with a shoulder to the helmet at the 37-yard line. 
There was no flag thrown for targeting on the play, which saw Harrington immediately spring up and plead to the officials for a 15-yard penalty, which would have moved the Cardinals into field goal range. 
Based on Rule 9-1-4, however, running backs aren't deemed to be defenseless players, so there was no grounds to throw a flag and Lamar didn't pick up another first down. 
"That's just how the rule is and that's just the interpretation of it I suppose," Woodard said. "That's what I saw though." 
The bigger argument Woodard could have made on Harrington's hit was that it was helmet-to-helmet contact, which constitutes the use of NCAA 9-1-3. 
Rule 9-1-3 states that "no player shall target and initiate contact against an opponent with the crown (top) of his helmet. When in question, it is a foul." 
Harrington's hit was questionable, so throwing a flag and having a replay review, even if it was deemed a clean hit, would have provided clarity. 
"Kade's I thought was helmet to helmet and should have been targeting," Woodard said. "That's how I saw it."
